Supported metal catalysts play an important role in various chemical reactions, including hydrogenation and dehydrogenation. Their activity and selectivity depend on factors such as the metal particle size and surface area and interaction between the metal and the support. Among these factors, “strong metal-support interaction” (SMSI) is a phenomenon by which metal particles supported on an oxide support are embedded under high-temperature reduction conditions, causing important changes in their surface adsorption properties and electronic states. Such electronic state changes reportedly alter the d-band centers of the metal and the adsorption energy of intermediates, thereby strongly influencing catalytic performance. For this study, we investigated SMSI effects on the selective hydrogenation of 4-chloronitrobenzene (4-ClNB) to 4-chloroaniline (4-ClAN) using a Pd/TiO2 catalyst. This reaction requires reduction of the -NO2 group while preventing dissociation of the -Cl group. Actually, Pd catalysts are known to have high reducing activity toward the -NO2 group, but they also cause undesirable C-Cl bond dissociation, which reduces their selectivity. By contrast, we found that controlling the electronic state of Pd via SMSI can enhance the selectivity to 4-ClAN. The underlying mechanisms were elucidated using TPR, TEM, CO adsorption, DRIFTS, XAFS, XPS, and DFT calculation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) Pd catalyst Reduction temperature Chemoselective hydrogenation Supported catalyst CO adsorption Data availability All data are shown in the main text and supporting information, and available on request. 1 Introduction Supported metal catalysts are used in various chemical reactions, including hydrogenation and dehydrogenation. Considerable effort has been made to improve their activity and selectivity [1–3]. Their activity is known to depend on the metal surface area and particle size, as well as the amount of metal loaded, whereas selectivity is affected by the metal-surface structure and the electronic state of metal by interactions with the support [4]. Regarding these, Tauster et al. discovered “strong metal-support interactions (SMSI)” as a specific interaction between the catalyst-support and the supported metal. This SMSI leads to the encapsulation of noble metal particles by oxide supports through high-temperature reduction, then the adsorbed amount of H2 and/or CO onto the noble metals decreases [5,6]. The electronic state of the supported active metal depends on its interaction with the support. Therefore, SMSI strongly affects the catalytic performance [7–10]. As a result, much work has been done on the circumstances under which SMSI can occur in supported metal catalysts. In addition, many studies have been conducted to clarify the structure and electronic state under which SMSI occurs [11–16]. Among these research efforts, Chien et al. used X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to analyze the electronic state of metal as SMSI occurred. They discovered charge transfer associated with interaction at the interface between the metal and the support [17]. The change in the electronic state of the active metal induced by SMSI affects the d-band center and adsorption energy of the adsorbate. Therefore, many studies have examined the interfacial electronic effects by SMSI [18–21]. He et al. found that Pdδ+ species with a deficiency of electrons by the metal-support interactions optimise the adsorption of oxygenated species such as *OH and *OOH, which are essential intermediates in the oxygen evolution reaction and exhibit high oxygen evolution reaction activity [22]. Huang et al. also found that doping Er into ZnO on a CuZnO catalyst promoted electron transfer from ZnO to Cu, and the electron-rich Cu δ− activated intermediates such as *CO3 and *CO, leading to high activity for the methanol synthesis reaction via CO2 hydrogenation [23]. A number of studies have been conducted on the impact of SMSI on catalytic activity and selectivity using various supported metal and oxide support combinations. Among these, Pd/TiO2, which combines Pd with a typical oxide support, TiO2, is one of the catalyst that has been studied extensively [24–26]. Notably, Pd/TiO2 is used in methanol synthesis by CO2 hydrogenation [27] and ethylene production from acetylene [28,29], in addition to various other selective hydrogenation reactions [30–34]. For this study, we specifically examined the reaction of 4-chloronitrobenzene to produce 4-chloroaniline, a key step in the phamaceutical synthesis, by selective hydrogenation using a Pd/TiO2 catalyst. To produce 4-chloroaniline in this reaction selectively, it is necessary to reduce the -NO2 group while suppressing dissociation of the -Cl group. However, although Pd catalysts have high reducing activity for the -NO2 group, they also entail the difficulty of easily causing dissociation of the -Cl group [35]. It is known that the electronic state of active metals can be controlled by SMSI [36–39]. We therefore attempted to improve the selectivity of 4-chloroaniline by controlling the electronic state of the supported palladium through the SMSI effect. Experimentally obtained results of CO pulse adsorption, diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) for CO adsorption, and XPS for Pd/TiO2 at different reduction temperatures showed that SMSI occurred when the reduction temperature was higher than 493 K, and that encapsulation of the metal by the support and changes in the electronic state occurred simultaneously. Results of the activity test demonstrated that the selectivity of 4-chloroaniline was improved by the occurrence of SMSI. Furthermore, when the adsorption ability of the -Cl group before and after reduction was compared using density functional theory (DFT) calculations, results showed that the change in the electronic state accompanying reduction caused electrostatic repulsion between the Pdδ− and the -Cl group. The selectivity of 4-chloroaniline was improved by suppressing adsorption of the -Cl group onto the Pd δ− after reduction by SMSI. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and chemicals Catalysts of 0.2 wt%Pd/TiO2 were synthesized using the impregnation method. After the catalyst support of anatase TiO2 was soaked in the aqueous solution of Pd(NO3)2, Pd was impregnated onto the support, followed by calcination in air at 773 K for 3 h. Then the catalyst was reduced by heating the sample at 10 K/min under a 100 % H2 atmosphere with a 50 mL/min flow rate, holding it at the target temperature for 1 h, and then cooling it to room temperature. Samples were prepared by varying the reduction temperatures to achieve various SMSI states. 2.2 Characterizations The Pd loading amount was confirmed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). H2-TPR (temperature programmed reduction) was performed to investigate the reducibility of the calcined catalyst. H2-TPR profiles were obtained using a catalyst analyzer (BELCAT-II; Microtrac-Bel Corp.). Before measurement, the sample (ca. 150 mg) was oxidized at 773 K under a 5 % O2/He 50 mL/min atmosphere for 30 min, followed by treatment at 773 K in an Ar 50 mL/min atmosphere for 30 min. Then H2-TPR was conducted by heating the sample at 10 K/min under a 5 % H2/Ar of 50 mL/min atmosphere. CO pulse adsorption measurements were conducted at 323 K using 5 % CO/He as the probe gas and He as the carrier gas at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. Prior to the measurement, the catalyst was pretreated by flowing O₂ 50 mL/min at 373 K, followed by He 50 mL/min, and then reduced at each temperature under H2 50 ml/min before cooling to the measurement temperature. The stoichiometric ratio used for the calculation of Pd particle size was assumed to be 1. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were measured using a microscope (Titan3 G2; FEI Co.). Pd K-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra were measured at the BL14B2 beamline of the SPring-8 facility. XANES analysis was performed using the xTunes program [40]. The XANES spectra were normalized after background subtraction using standard procedures, including pre-edge subtraction and edge-step normalization, as performed with the xTunes software. The pre-edge background and EXAFS background were subtracted using the McMaster and Cubicspline methods, respectively. As standard references, Pd foil and PdO samples available at BL14B2 were also measured. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed (VersaProbe 4; PHI) to evaluate differences in electronic states under different reduction conditions. The calcined sample was reduced in a pre-treatment chamber attached to the XPS instrument and was analyzed without exposure to air. All the binding energies of elements were calibrated with the C1 s peak at 284.8 eV. Curve fitting was performed using a Gauss-Lorentz function with an Iterated Shirley background. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) for CO adsorption was conducted using an FT-IR spectrophotometer (FT/IR-4600; Jasco Corp.) equipped with a ZnSe window and an MCT detector. The spectra were recorded at a resolution of 4 cm-¹ and 100 scans. DRIFTS measurements were taken after reducing the calcined samples at different temperatures. 2.3 Catalytic reaction Hydrogenation of 4-chloronitrobenzene (4-ClNB) was conducted in a trickle-bed reactor. The reaction conditions were the following: reaction temperature of 313 K, liquid flow rate of 0.5 mL/min (4-ClNB = 0.1 mol/L, toluene: isopropyl alcohol = 2: 1), and gas flow rate of 50 mL/min (100 % H2). The catalyst weight was 0.26 g. Catalytic performance tests were conducted using samples reduced under different conditions. Products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). The yield (Y) and selectivity (S) were calculated using the following equations. Y 4 − Cl AN = n ( 4 − Cl AN ) n 0 ( 4 − ClNB ) inlet S 4 − ClAN = n 4 − ClAN n 0 4 − ClNB outlet + n 4 − ClAN + n AN + n ( NB ) Here, n 0(4-ClNB) represents the molar amount of the reactant 4-chloronitrobenzene, and n(4-ClAN), n(AN), n(NB) represents the molar amounts of the products 4-chloroaniline, aniline, nitrobenzene, respectively. No other products were detected. 2.4 Theoretical calculation All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using software (Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package, VASP ver. 6.2.1) [41,42]. Exchange correlation functional was treated using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [43]. Interactions between the core and valence electrons were described using the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [44], with the plane-wave cutoff energy set as 400 eV. Monkhorst-Pack grids for k-points were set as 6 × 6 × 6 for bulk models and 2 × 2 × 1 for slab models [45]. The slab model used in the calculations was obtained by cutting a 3 × 1 18-atomic-layer slab from the anatase TiO2 (101) bulk model. A vacuum layer of 15 Å was applied. During structural optimisation, the bottom six layers were fixed, whereas the top 12 layers were relaxed. A Pd four-atom cluster was deposited on the TiO2 surface to represent the Pd particle. The deposition method followed procedures reported earlier in the relevant literature [46,47]. To simulate the reduced state in the DFT calculations, an oxygen vacancy was introduced into the reduced model to represent the reduced surface. All calculation models were visualized using VESTA (Visualization for Electronic and STructural Analysis) [48]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Reduction properties and structural changes with reduction temperature To determine the reduction characteristics of 0.2 wt% Pd/TiO2, TPR measurements for the catalyst were conducted. Results are shown in Fig. 1. Supported Pd was reduced at around 300 K or less, so the TPR results exhibited a reduction peak at 500 K to 800 K attributed to the reduction of TiO2 [49,50], and Pd impregnation promotes the low-temperature reduction of TiO2. This low-temperature reduction of TiO2 is ascribed to the enhanced reducibility of TiO2 by dissociated hydrogen atoms provided by the noble metal [51]. In addition, the onset temperatures of TiO₂ reduction were estimated by determining the intersection point between the TPR baseline and the rising edge of the TiO₂ reduction peak. The reduction onset was observed at 530.5 K for bare TiO₂ and at 491.1 K for 0.2 wt% Pd/TiO₂, indicating that Pd loading promotes TiO₂ reduction by approximately 40 K and that reduction of the support begins at 491.1 K in the Pd-loaded sample. To investigate the local structure of Pd after metal and support reduction, HAADF-STEM observation was conducted. Fig. 2 shows HAADF-STEM images of the 0.2 wt% Pd/TiO2 before the reduction, after reduction at 423 K, and after reduction at 573 K. Pd particles of approximately 1 nm size were observed for all samples. Energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping (Fig. S1) confirmed that Pd was highly dispersed on the surface, verifying that the particles observed in the HAADF-STEM images were indeed Pd. The Pd particle size distributions obtained from these images indicated that the average particle sizes were 1.56 nm before reduction, 1.31 nm after reduction at 423 K, and 1.54 nm after reduction at 573 K, indicating that no significant particle aggregation occurred during the reduction process. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements of the three samples revealed only peaks corresponding to TiO2, indicating that Pd remained highly dispersed even after reduction at 573 K (Fig. S2). By contrast, CO pulse adsorption revealed a marked decrease in the CO adsorption amount after the reduction at temperatures higher than 493 K as shown in Fig. 3. The particle size estimated from CO adsorption data ( Table 1) showed a particle size of 5.4 nm after reduction at 493 K and 14.0 nm after reduction at 573 K. Although TEM measurements showed no marked change in Pd particle size after reduction at 573 K, CO pulse adsorption demonstrated a decrease in CO adsorption amount above 493 K. These results suggest that SMSI occurred at temperatures higher than 493 K, where the Pd surface was encapsulated by the TiO2 support, thereby reducing the CO adsorption capacity. 3.2 Electronic state changes with reduction temperature The electronic state of Pd after reduction at different temperatures was analyzed using XAFS, XPS, and DRIFTS CO adsorption spectra. Fig. 4 shows the XAFS spectra after reduction at 323 K, 423 K and 573 K. As the reduction temperature increased, the white line intensity decreased, indicating an increase in the proportion of Pd0. To quantitatively support this observation, linear combination fitting (LCF) was performed using Pd foil and PdO as reference compounds available at the BL14B2 beamline, and the results are summarized in Table S1. The fitting confirmed that the fraction of Pd0 increased with higher reduction temperatures, indicating progressive reduction. The corresponding XAFS data are also provided in Fig. S3. The Pd 3d XPS spectra obtained after reduction at different temperatures are presented in Fig. 5. The spectra were deconvoluted into two components corresponding to Pd0 and Pd2+ species. The results of this deconvolution analysis, including the relative ratios, binding energies, and full width at half maximum (FWHM) values for each component, are summarised in Table S2. The ratio of Pd0 increased with increasing reduction temperature, which is consistent with the XAFS results. In terms of binding energy, the Pd0 component was located 335.7 eV, while the Pd2+ component appeared 336.7 eV [52]. At a reduction temperature above 493 K, the Pd0 peak shifted slightly to a lower binding energy. (335.5 eV as shown in Table S2) [53]. This shift suggests an increase in electron density on Pd, possibly resulting from electron transfer from TiO2 support. This electronic change is likely associated with the occurrence of strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [54,55]. The Ti 2p and O1 s XPS spectra (Fig. S4, Table S3 and Table S4) showed no remarkable changes, indicating that reduction of TiO2 occurred only in a localised region near the Pd particles [56]. DRIFTS CO adsorption spectra ( Fig. 6) further confirmed the change in the electronic state of Pd. The peaks at 2141 cm-¹ and 2080 cm-¹ corresponded respectively to on-top CO adsorption on Pd²+ and Pd0 [57–59]. The spectra showed that after reduction at 303 K, surface Pd was reduced. Also, after reduction at temperatures higher than 493 K, the CO stretching vibration on Pd0 shifted to a lower wavenumber. A negative charge on Pd is known to enhance back-donation to CO, resulting in a red shift of the CO stretching vibration [60,61]. This result confirmed that electron transfer from TiO2 to Pd occurred because of SMSI after reduction at temperatures higher than 493 K. The peaks at approximately 1965 cm-¹ and 1920 cm-¹ in Fig. 6 respectively correspond to bridge adsorption of CO on edge and terrace sites [33,62,63]. Reduction up to 423 K favoured adsorption on edge sites, whereas reduction at 453 K decreased CO bridge adsorption on edge sites. Reduction at temperatures higher than 493 K caused almost no edge site adsorption, with terrace site adsorption becoming dominant, which indicates that, for the catalyst used for this study, encapsulation of Pd by the support occurred preferentially at edge sites, with terrace sites remaining exposed on the surface. 3.3 Catalytic activity and selectivity after reduction Next, we conducted the hydrogenation of 4-chloronitrobenzene (4-ClNB) to 4-chloroaniline (4-ClAN) using these various 0.2 wt%Pd/TiO2 catalysts to elucidate effects of reduction temperature on catalytic activity and selectivity. As portrayed in Fig. 7, reduction at 493 K and higher temperatures, where SMSI occurred, caused a marked decrease in yield but led to an improvement in selectivity. The hydrogenation of 4-ClNB to 4-ClAN is a sequential reaction that produces aniline (AN) as a by-product, because of -Cl group dissociation after 4-ClAN formation. To reveal these phenomena, catalytic tests were conducted at different reduction temperatures under conditions where the conversion of 4-ClNB was adjusted to the same conversion (Fig. S5). Results demonstrated that reduction at 573 K led to clear improvement in selectivity, indicating that the increase in selectivity was not attributable to the decrease in yield. These findings suggest that although the decrease in yield after reduction at 493 K or higher was attributable to the encapsulation of Pd by TiO2, the improvement in selectivity was likely to be attributable to changes in the local structure and electronic state of Pd caused by SMSI. Particularly during the hydrogenation of 4-ClNB to 4-ClAN, changes in the electronic state of the active sites, such as through alloying, are known to affect the dissociation ability of the -Cl group and the reducibility of the -NO2 group [36–38]. Moreover, DRIFTS CO adsorption measurements confirmed that Pd exhibited a negatively charged state after the reduction at 493 K and higher, and it highlights the influence of electronic state changes on selectivity. The nature of the reduced catalysts is shown in the Figs. S6-9. We also confirmed the stability and reusability of this catalyst, and the results show good stability and reusability, as shown in Fig. S10-11. To gain a more detailed understanding of how SMSI-induced changes in the electronic state affected the hydrogenation of 4-ClNB to 4-ClAN, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to investigate how the electronic state of Pd influences selectivity. 3.4 Investigation of selectivity enhancement by SMSI through DFT calculations DFT calculations were conducted to investigate effects of electronic state changes observed in XPS and DRIFTS CO adsorption spectra on the improved selectivity of 4-ClAN. In the hydrogenation reaction of 4-ClNB to 4-ClAN, the byproducts are nitrobenzene (NB) and aniline (AN). Dissociation of the -Cl group in 4-ClAN generates AN as a byproduct, which affects selectivity. Therefore, suppressing the dissociation of the -Cl group in 4-ClAN is crucially important for improving selectivity. Because this dissociation proceeds via -Cl group adsorption on the Pd surface, evaluating the adsorption strength of the -Cl group on Pd is particularly important. For this study, DFT calculations were performed to compare the adsorption strength of the -Cl group of 4-ClAN on the Pd surface before and after reduction of the support, thereby elucidating the factors contributing to the improved selectivity. Reduction of the support is crucial for SMSI to occur. To model this reduction, oxygen vacancies were introduced around the Pd cluster. Structural optimisation after introducing oxygen vacancies revealed that the Pd cluster spread over the TiO2 surface. This structural change was attributed to the increase in surface energy of TiO2 caused by reduction, which induced structural rearrangement of the Pd cluster. Fig. 8 presents the results of the Bader charge analysis before and after the reduction of TiO2. As shown in that figure, the Pd before TiO2 reduction exhibited a positive charge, whereas the Pd after reduction exhibited a negative charge. This result was consistent with XPS and DRIFTS findings, confirming that electron transfer occurred from TiO2 to Pd thanks to SMSI. In this calculation, important structural changes occurred before and after the reduction. To confirm that the negative charge in the electronic state of Pd was attributable to the reduction of TiO2 rather than to structural changes, Bader charge analysis was performed on a model where no structural optimisation was conducted after TiO2 reduction (Fig. S12). The results demonstrated that even in the model without structural optimisation, Pd exhibited a negative charge, particularly around the oxygen vacancy sites. This finding confirmed that the reduction of TiO2 is necessary for electron transfer from TiO2 to Pd. To examine the effects of this charge-change on the adsorption of the -Cl group in 4-ClAN further, structural optimization was performed after adsorbing only the -Cl group of 4-ClAN onto Pd. Results are shown in Fig. 9. When the -Cl group was adsorbed onto Pd before TiO2 reduction, the -Cl group remained adsorbed even after structural optimization. However, after TiO2 reduction, structural optimization revealed that the -Cl group was desorbed from the Pd surface. These results suggest that the negative shift in the electronic state of Pd caused by SMSI led to electrostatic repulsion of the -Cl group in 4-ClAN, thereby suppressing -Cl group dissociation and contributing to enhanced selectivity. 4 Conclusion For this study, we investigated the role of SMSI in enhancing the selectivity of the hydrogenation reaction of 4-ClNB to 4-ClAN using Pd/TiO2 catalysts reduced under various temperatures. Pd efficiently reduces the -NO2 group but simultaneously promotes the unwanted dissociation of the -Cl group, leading to a decrease in selectivity. By controlling the pre-reduction temperature of the catalyst, we succeeded in suppressing the C-Cl bond dissociation and improving the selectivity to 4-CIAN by controlling the electronic state of Pd via SMSI. Characterization techniques such as TPR, HAADF-STEM, and CO pulse chemical adsorption were employed, revealing that SMSI initiates at reduction temperatures higher than 493 K. Although no marked change in Pd particle size was observed using microscopy or XRD analysis, the considerable reduction in CO adsorption indicated that Pd was incorporated into the TiO2 support and that SMSI occurred. Further detailed investigations using XAFS, XPS, and DRIFTS CO adsorption revealed that the content of metallic Pd0 increased and that the binding energy of Pd shifted in the negative direction with increasing reduction temperature. These changes indicate that electron transfer from TiO2 to Pd generated more electron-rich Pd surfaces. DFT calculations supported these results, demonstrating that the negatively charged Pd δ− surface repels the -Cl groups of 4-ClAN, thereby preventing their dissociation. Consequently, these findings demonstrated that SMSI induced by controlling the reduction temperature adjusts the electronic state of Pd and enhances selectivity in hydrogenation reactions. These results underscore the strategic value of SMSI in the design of more selective and efficient support metal catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Supported metal catalysts play an important role in various chemical reactions, including hydrogenation and dehydrogenation. Their activity and selectivity depend on factors such as the metal particle size and surface area and interaction between the metal and the support. Among these factors, “strong metal-support interaction” (SMSI) is a phenomenon by which metal particles supported on an oxide support are embedded under high-temperature reduction conditions, causing important changes in their surface adsorption properties and electronic states. Such electronic state changes reportedly alter the d-band centers of the metal and the adsorption energy of intermediates, thereby strongly influencing catalytic performance. For this study, we investigated SMSI effects on the selective hydrogenation of 4-chloronitrobenzene (4-ClNB) to 4-chloroaniline (4-ClAN) using a Pd/TiO2 catalyst. This reaction requires reduction of the -NO2 group while preventing dissociation of the -Cl group. Actually, Pd catalysts are known to have high reducing activity toward the -NO2 group, but they also cause undesirable C-Cl bond dissociation, which reduces their selectivity. By contrast, we found that controlling the electronic state of Pd via SMSI can enhance the selectivity to 4-ClAN. The underlying mechanisms were elucidated using TPR, TEM, CO adsorption, DRIFTS, XAFS, XPS, and DFT calculation.

coredata.dc:title: Enhancing chemoselectivity via strong metal-support interaction: Selective hydrogenation of 4-chloronitrobenzene over Pd/TiO2 catalysts
